channel.title: NYT > Top Stories

item.title: Judge Grants Trump’s Request for Special Master to Review Mar-a-Lago Documents
item.description: The ruling also effectively barred federal prosecutors from using key pieces of evidence as they continue to investigate whether Mr. Trump illegally retained national defense documents at his estate.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal judge said that a special master could evaluate the documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s estate.

item.title: Liz Truss to Replace Boris Johnson at a Time of Crisis for Britain
item.description: Ms. Truss, who prevailed over Rishi Sunak, will be greeted by an array of vexing problems, including double-digit inflation, a looming recession, labor unrest and soaring household energy bills.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Liz Truss at the Conservative Party headquarters in London on Monday after it was announced that she had prevailed in the contest to be Britain's next prime minister.

item.title: As U.K. Prime Minister, Liz Truss Will Face Hard Times
item.description: Coming to power during the worst economic crisis since the Thatcher era, Liz Truss will need all her ideological dexterity — some call it opportunism — to succeed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Liz Truss in London on Monday after it was announced she had won the contest to become Britain’s next prime minister. Colleagues speak of her nerve, drive and appetite for disruptive politics.

item.title: Breaking Taboo, Germany Extends Life of 2 Nuclear Reactors
item.description: The step is intended to cushion a growing energy crisis in Europe but could upend the country’s plans to become the first industrial power to shutter its program.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Alexandra Beier/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Isar 2 nuclear power plant in Essenbach, Germany.

item.title: Climate Change Is Ravaging the Colorado River. There’s a Model to Avert the Worst.
item.description: Success in the Yakima River Basin in Washington holds lessons for the seven states at war over water in the American West.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and Ruth Fremson

item.title: In Montauk, Big Money Moves In on a Surfers’ Paradise
item.description: The acres overlooking a prize stretch of Long Island’s East End were empty for years. Now they’ve been sold in multimillion-dollar deals. It’s been the talk of the beach all summer.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Kenyon Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surfers at Ditch Plains Beach, a part of Montauk known for its consistent waves.

item.title: With Voters From Both Parties Energized, Campaigns Begin Fall Sprint
item.description: Republicans are focusing on pocketbook issues, and Democrats are emphasizing abortion rights, as Labor Day marks the start of the midterm elections’ final stretch.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Cheyenne, Wyo., during the state primary in August. Political upheaval around a variety of issues has heightened the sense that the country’s political system is dysfunctional.

item.title: China Imposes More Covid Lockdowns, Stoking Anxiety
item.description: Nearly every province has recorded infections in recent days, leaving some 60 million residents locked down. Weariness is growing by the day as the restrictions go on seemingly without end.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A testing site in Chengdu, China, on Friday, during a lockdown. The city’s testing system collapsed over the weekend, leaving residents waiting in line for hours.

item.title: The Hunt for Big Hail
item.description: Hailstones of record size are falling left and right, and hailstorm damage is growing. But there is surprisingly little research to explain why.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Mike Coniglio/NOAA
item.media:description: A supercell thunderstorm threatening to engulf a barn near Imperial, Neb., in 2019. Almost all hail is created in supercells, or storms with updrafts of rising air that slowly rotate.

item.title: Of Barbecues and Men: A Summer Storm Brews Over Virility in France
item.description: A Green politician told men to get over meat and masculinity for the sake of the planet, setting off a sizzling argument.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Benoit Tessier/Reuters
item.media:description: Sandrine Rousseau, a member of parliament from the Greens, has thrust barbecue to the center of French debate.

item.title: John McEnroe Gets His Revenge
item.description: While other stars fade, the notorious “Super Brat” has become a subject of fascination and a ubiquitous presence, inside tennis and outside it, too. You have a problem with that?
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Clive Brunskill/Getty Images For Laver Cup
item.media:description: John McEnroe during the 2021 Laver Cup.

item.title: Jonathan Pie on Liz Truss, Britain’s Next Prime Minister
item.description: With Liz Truss as its next prime minister, Britain is about to get a second helping of the policies that created its current crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Pie and Adam Westbrook

item.title: Abortion and Trump Are Giving Democrats a Shot
item.description: This may be a year when politics gets flipped on its head.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Student Journalists Reveal a Changing World. Let Them.
item.description: The shutdown of a high school newspaper in Nebraska is only the latest episode in efforts to censor student publications across red states.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Even With Biden as a Pro-Labor Champion, Unionizing Is Still a Grind
item.description: A flurry of new organizing efforts is giving young people hope.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Everyone
item.description: Our democracy sprouts in the nursery of public schools — where students grapple, together, with our messy history and learn to negotiate differences.
item.dc:creator: Anya Kamenetz
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Ansel Adams, Esther Bubley, Warren K. Leffler and Russell Lee, via Library of Congress; Museums Victoria, Muhammad Haikal Sjurki, Note Thanun and New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Merit
item.description: Merit demands excellence and rigor. It is not, as its critics often insist, an elitist, classist or racist value.
item.dc:creator: Asra Q. Nomani
item.category: Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology (Fairfax, Va)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; photos-public-domain.com; Sam Samannejad and Gabriela Testa, via Unsplash; and Calsidyrose, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: Has Bidenomics Been Good for Workers?
item.description: Yes, creating millions of jobs is a good thing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Maria Contreras Coll for The New York Times

item.title: What’s Behind the Pileup of Sex Abuse Scandals?
item.description: Sociologists see a pattern that goes beyond the culture of specific schools, churches and industries: an ingrained resistance to self-policing or defying a community’s hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.media:credit: Rick Bowmer/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Salt Lake City, Utah.

item.title: David Sedaris’s Diaries
item.description: The essayist talks about his book “Theft by Finding,” a selection of diary entries spanning 25 years that helped him find and shape his voice as a writer.

item.title: Good Things to Make With Summer Corn
item.description: Raw, stir-fried, grilled and puréed — there’s a corn recipe for every mood.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Money to Burn: Lessons From the Premier League’s Transfer Window
item.description: English teams awash in cash broke records for players and prices this summer, proving again that they operate on a plane apart from their rivals.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: David Klein/Reuters
item.media:description: Sign the stars, sell the shirts, repeat.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Shakes Southwestern China
item.description: State media said more than 30 people were killed, but communications in the landslide-prone area were disrupted and the full damage was unclear.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A road in China’s Sichuan Province after an earthquake on Monday, in a photo from the Chinese news agency Xinhua.

item.title: Israel Says Shireen Abu Akleh Most Likely Shot by Israeli Soldier
item.description: The Israeli Army has concluded that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American broadcaster, was probably killed by one of its own soldiers — but stopped short of accepting definitive blame.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site where Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American journalist, was shot and killed in the West Bank town of Jenin.

item.title: West Indian Parade Returns After Two-Year Covid Hiatus
item.description: Scenes from the Labor Day tradition, which returned to Brooklyn after it had been canceled for two years because of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Brian Josephs
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: At this year’s J’Ouvert — a french word that translates to “daybreak” — floats began their trip from East Flatbush to Grand Army Plaza, the festival’s start route, soon after midnight.

item.title: In Louisiana, a Quiet Hurricane Season Brings Little Relief
item.description: The season has gotten off to an unusually calm start, but the absence of storms has only ratcheted up the anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times
item.media:description: Susie Fawvor in her family home that was built in 1915. It has withstood every major hurricane since its construction but was damaged in Hurricane Laura and is still in need of repairs.

item.title: How to Cope With Fall Anxiety
item.description: As the most carefree weeks of the year draw to a close, pay close attention to your emotions. They might be telling you something useful.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasus

item.title: The Secret to Raising a Resilient Kid
item.description: The ability to bounce back is more important now than ever; here’s how to impart it
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance
item.media:credit: Joao Fazenda

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.
